text: Hello. I'm using TYPO3 as a CMS for over 10 years and I did many many HTML templates for it, usually based on Bootstrap. I'm pretty new to HubSpot CMS and I try to understand the logic. I get the idea with the deployment of the Templates but what is still a question for me and I couldn't a proper answer online is. When I take the HubSpot CMS Boilerplate there are already so many CSS rules given and also a Grid framework. Do you build your templates on that or do you add Bootstrap 5 to have all the styles from it and also SCSS support. I'm just curious, whats your workflow?

My recommendation is to adapt or addon to the existing styles and grid. HubSpot internal team build new functionality based on these core styles. This will make your theme better support future things. I know it isn't the most liberating but why reinvent the wheel?
Thx for your reply. I'm just curious - if you build something you just add your own CSS without any other framework?
Correct. I just use BEM css naming, I do add bootstrap 4 utility classes for responsive flexbox. Once I am done with dev, I run my code through autoprefixer.
So less invasive and anyone can pickup and edit without having to compile a bunch of stuff. But this is just me. Curious to hear what others think.
Do you mind if I ask something else to understand the logic. Have you ever changed the quote themes? Do you just add another theme and change the "basic.html" up?
Having worked on custom quotes yet. None of my clients have sales pro to try

<@U033VNNBBBP> unless you're reusing code from a CMS theme, a dedicated quotes theme is probably overkill. I would just upload as a standard project folder to the design manager. I believe the docs have a boilerplate for those templates as well
